Fig. 1 XRD patterns of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 (a), 5 wt% Pd/La2O3 (b), 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 (c) and 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 (d) catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TPR profiles of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 (a), 5 wt% Pd/La2O3 (b), 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 (c) and 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 (d) catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM images of 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 (a), 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 (b),5 wt% Pd/La2O3 (c) and 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 (d) catalysts, HAADF-STEM and element mapping images of 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst (e-i). The inset in (a) is the HRTEM image corresponding to the labeled regions. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS spectra of C1s (a), O1s (b) and Pd 3d (c) of supported Pd catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 EPR spectra of supported Pd catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Concentration-time curves of 4-FP during HDF over supported Pd catalysts (a), and the corresponding TOF values (b). Reaction conditions: temperature (25 °C), catalyst dosage (0.5 g/L), 4-FP concentration (0.5 mmol/L), reaction volume (40 mL). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Concentration-time curves of 4-FP during HDF over 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 (a), 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 (b) and 5 wt% Pd/La2O3 (c), and the corresponding k values (d). Oxygen vacancies promoted catalytic hydrodefluorination over Pd/La2O3 catalyst for the efficient degradation of fluorophenols at mild condition Linyu Li Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Haozhen Feng Investigation Lizhi Tan Methodology Investigation Hong Lin Formal analysis Jun Xiong Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Department of Pharmaceutical Engineering, School of Pharmacy and Key Laboratory of Basic Pharmacology of Guizhou Province, Zunyi Medical University, Zunyi, Guizhou 563000, China Department of Pharmaceutical Engineering, School of Pharmacy and Key Laboratory of Basic Pharmacology of Guizhou Province, Zunyi Medical University Zunyi Guizhou 563000 China Department of Pharmaceutical Engineering, School of Pharmacy and Key Laboratory of Basic Pharmacology of Guizhou Province, Zunyi Medical University, Zunyi, Guizhou, 563000, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The efficient hydrodefluorination at mild conditions is a huge challenge during catalytic hydrodefluorination for the treatment of wastewater containing fluorophenols. The application of lanthanum oxide as the catalyst support for the Pd-catalyzed hydrodefluorination of fluorophenols was proposed. It was found that the Pd/La2O3 catalyst exhibited a much higher HDF activity than other catalysts. Further investigation of the reaction kinetic and mechanism revealed that the oxygen vacancy promoting mechanism was dominant during HDF of 4-fluorophenol over Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst with rich oxygen vacancies has a high HDF activity, fully degrading the 4-fluorophenol within 120 min at mild condition. The calculated TOF of this catalyst (0.34293 min−1) is more than 70 times that of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst, making it to be a promising candidate for the hydrodefluorination of fluorophenols. Graphical Abstract Keywords Catalytic hydrodefluorination Pd/La2O3 catalyst Fluorophenols Oxygen vacancies Heterogeneous catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The environmental pollution issues related to the halogenated phenolic compounds have attracted increasing concern, due to their acute toxicity, serious bioaccumulation potential and poor biodegradability [1–6]. Fluorophenols (FPs), as a significant class of emerging environmental pollutants are frequently found in the wastewater effluents of pharmaceutical, pesticide, dyestuff and liquid crystal [7–10]. These compounds have also been listed in persistent organic pollutants (POPs) under the Stockholm Convention [11]. The FPs exhibit strong resistance to the traditional biodegradation and oxidation degradation, because of the high stability of the C-F bond [12–14]. It is urgent to develop effective methods for the safe disposal of wastewater containing fluorophenols. Catalytic hydrodehalogenation (HDH), using supported transition metal catalysts and molecular hydrogen (H2), is considered as a highly efficient and environmentally friendly method for degrading chlorophenols and bromophenols [15–17]. This technique has also been widely proposed for the defluorination of fluoroorganic compounds including fluorophenols [17–20]. Unfortunately, the strong C-F bonds are difficult to break, resulting in low defluorinating efficiency during catalytic hydrodefluorination (HDF) [8,17,21]. Although the enhanced HDF performance can be obtained under harsh reaction conditions (e.g. high temperature, high H2 pressure and toxic organic solvent) [21,22], achieving efficient hydrodefluorination of FPs at mild conditions remains a huge challenge. The catalyst is the key factor in determining the catalytic performance during HDH [15,23]. So far, the HDF activity of conventional supported transition metal catalysts (e.g. Pd/SiO2, Pd/C and Rh/SiO2) in the aqueous phase has been poor, especially at mild condition [17,21,22]. Further development of new catalysts with high HDF activity is required for the efficient degradation of FPs. The HDH performance is greatly influenced by the support properties of catalyst [24,25]. It is vital to achieve a high HDF performance, by employing a suitable catalyst support. Lanthanum oxide (La2O3) is well known as the catalyst support and catalytic promoter in heterogeneous catalysis, due to its unique chemical properties and strong interaction with active metal [15,26–28]. The relatively rich oxygen vacancies in this material may be crucial for many heterogeneous catalytic reactions [29,30]. More importantly, the presence of La in catalyst has been proved to be effective in enhancing the HDH activity of supported Pd and Rh catalysts [15,31]. Therefore, the application of lanthanum oxide as the catalyst support may be interesting for accelerating the HDF of FPs. In this work, we developed a series of Pd catalysts for the efficient degradation of FPs through HDF, utilizing La2O3 as the catalyst support. It was found that the La2O3 could serve as an excellent support for Pd-catalyzed HDF of FPs at mild conditions. The Pd/La2O3 catalyst exhibited significantly higher HDF activity, compared to the Pd/SiO2, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/carbon nanotubes (Pd/CNTs) catalysts. The high HDF efficiency of Pd/La2O3 catalyst is closely related to the oxygen vacancies. Kinetics and mechanism studies were carried out to further investigate the oxygen vacancy promoting effect on the HDF of FPs over Pd/La2O3 catalyst. Finally, the HDF performances over Pd/La2O3 catalyst were optimized. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Palladium chloride (PdCl2, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd), 4-Fluorophenol (4-FP, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd) and other chemicals were used without further purification. The lanthanum oxide (La2O3), silicon oxide (SiO2) and aluminum oxide (Al2O3) were purchased from Xfnano Co., Ltd. The graphite multi-wall carbon nanotubes (MCNTs) were provided by Chengdu Organic Chemicals Co. Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation All the supported Pd catalysts were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method. In the typical preparation of Pd/La2O3 catalyst, 100 mg La2O3 was added to 2 mL PdCl2 acidic solution containing a given amount of Pd. The slurry mixture was subjected to 30 mins ultrasonic treatment, then placed into a water-bathing constant temperature vibrator at 90 °C, and dried under a shaking speed of 100 rpm. Subsequently, the dried powder sample was calcined in air at 300 °C for 2 h and reduced by hydrogen gas (30 mL/min) at 450 °C for 1 h. The Pd/SiO2, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/CNTs catalysts were also prepared, according to the similar preparation process. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a SmartLab SE X-ray diffraction meter equipped with a Cu Ka radiation source. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), High-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and Element mapping images were acquired by the JEOL-2100 F electron microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha photoelectron spectrometer. XPS binding energies were calibrated by setting the C 1 s peak from adventitious carbon to 284.8 eV. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were conducted at 100 K in liquid nitrogen on a Bruker EMXplus spectrometer. Pd contents in catalyst samples were measured by the inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrophotometer (ICP-OES) performed on an Agilent 5110 spectrometer. Infrared (IR) spectra between 400 and 4000 cm−1 were recorded on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS20 infrared spectrometer. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were determined at −196 °C on the ASAP 2020 volumetric adsorption analyzers manufactured by Micromeritics. The specific surface area (SSA) of each sample was obtained by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The Pd dispersion (D) of catalyst was determined, based on the pulsed CO chemisorption result performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. The Pd dispersion was calculated as follows: D ( % ) = S f × M A × V a d m × W × V m × 100 Where S f =stoichiometry factor (1); M A =the atomic mass of Pd (106.42 g/mol); V ad =the volume of chemisorbed CO at standard temperature and pressure conditions (mL); V m =the molar volume of CO (22.414 L/mol) at standard temperature and pressure conditions; m=the mass of the sample (g); W=the weight fraction of Pd in the sample determined by ICP-OES. 2.4 Catalytic performance testing The HDF activities of various Pd catalysts at mild conditions (25 °C and ambient pressure) were evaluated in a glass batch reactor with an inner diameter of 15 mm, using 4-FP as the model substrate. Initially, 20 mg catalyst was added to 38 mL water at 25 °C with a stirring speed of 1500 rpm. The H2 gas (0.3 MPa, 10 mL/min) was then continuously fed from the bottom of reactor. Prior to the addition of 2 mL aqueous 4-FP solution (10 mmol/L), the Pd catalyst was pre-saturated with hydrogen for 30 min. During the HDF process, the liquid mixture were sampled and analyzed by the high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with an UV detector at 280 nm and a Kromstar C18 column. The mobile phase, consisting of 30 % methanol and 70 % water (v:v), flows at a rate of 1.0 mL/min. For a better comparison of HDF activities over different Pd catalysts, the turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated according to the following formulae [32,33]: T O F ( min − 1 ) = r 0 × M A × 10 − 3 D × 100 Where r 0 , D and M A are the initial HDF rate (mmol/min gmetal), Pd dispersion (%) and the atomic mass of Pd (106.42 g/mol), respectively. In the reusability evaluation, the used 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst was filtrated and washed with the deionized water, then dried at 40 °C under vacuum for the next run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Table 1 summarizes the physical properties of Pd/SiO2 and Pd/La2O3 catalysts. It was found that the Pd contents in all the catalysts were well consistent with the calculated values. The specific surface area of Pd/SiO2 sample (116.60 m2/g) is about 20 times of those of Pd/La2O3 catalysts, because of the high specific surface area property of SiO2 support. The higher Pd dispersion and smaller Pd particle size were also presented by the Pd/SiO2 catalyst. For the Pd/La2O3 catalysts, the Pd dispersion is influenced significantly by the Pd content in catalyst. The Pd dispersion of Pd/La2O3 catalyst decreases from 35.8 % to 14.3 % by increasing the Pd content from 0.2 to 5 wt%. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Pd/SiO2 and Pd/La2O3 catalysts. The diffraction peak of 40.1°, corresponding to the (111) plane of Pd, were observed in all XRD patterns, indicating the presence of metallic Pd in these catalysts [34,35]. In the XRD pattern of 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst, the peaks of La2O3 phase disappeared and the strong characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to the hexagonal phase of La2O2CO3 were clearly observed (PDF:37–0804) [36]. The crystalline phase transfer from La2O3 to La2O2CO3 can be attributed to the reaction between La2O3 and CO2 in air during catalyst preparation [26,37,38]. The La2O3 is prone to strongly interact with the noble metals such as Pd, Rh and Pt [15,31,39]. The strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) in Pd/La2O3 catalysts may even results in the generation of lanthanum-palladium oxide (La2O3·xPdO) phase [31,40]. That is why the diffraction peaks of La2O3·xPdO phase were presented in the XRD pattern of 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst. In the case of 5 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst with a high Pd content, the La2O2CO3 phase vanished and was replaced by the La2O3·xPdO phase. These results suggested that the SMSI between Pd and La2O3 hindered the reaction of CO2 and La2O3, suppressing the formation of La2O2CO3 in the Pd/La2O3 catalyst with a high Pd loading. The suppression of high Pd content on the formation of La2O2CO3 in Pd/La2O3 catalyst was also found during the H2-TPR characterization ( Fig. 2). In the H2-TPR profile of 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst, a strong reduction peak at the high temperature of 750 °C, attributing to the hydrogen consumption of CO2 produced by the decomposition of La2O2CO3, was observed [30,41]. This reduction peak intensity decreased significantly with the increasing of Pd content, and vanished in the H2-TPR profile of 5 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The above H2-TPR analysis revealed that the formation of La2O2CO3 in Pd/La2O3 catalyst could be greatly hindered by enhancing the Pd content. Simultaneously, the active Pd-support interactions of Pd/SiO2 and Pd/La2O3 catalysts were investigated. Only a weak Pd2+ reduction peak centered around 150 °C was presented by the Pd/SiO2 catalyst, indicating a weak interaction between Pd and SiO2 support [2,42]. However, a strong Pd-support interaction occurs in Pd/La2O3 catalysts. For 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst, there are two other Pd2+ reduction peaks at higher temperatures of about 380 °C and 470 °C, in addition to the Pd2+ reduction peak at low temperature of about 150 °C. The former is associated with the reduction of Pd2+ species that strongly interact with support, while the latter can be assigned to the reduction of stable La2O3·xPdO phase [2,31]. The Pd2+ reduction peaks at higher temperature intensifies significantly, as the Pd content changes from 0.2 to 5 wt%, suggesting that the interaction between active Pd and support in Pd/La2O3 catalyst is greatly strengthened by enhancing the Pd content. Fig. 3a shows the TEM image of 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The nearly spherical nanoparticles, with a mean particle size of about 3.1 nm (Table 1), were clearly observed on support (La2O2CO3). HRTEM characterization revealed that the observed nanoparticles in this catalyst were crystalline Pd nanoparticles, which was consistent with the XRD analysis. The 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst sample was further characterized by the HAADF-STEM and element mapping. The presence of Pd, La, O and C elements in catalyst was established, and the active Pd element was highly dispersed (Fig. 3e-i). The similar morphology and Pd nanoparticles size were also presented by 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst (Fig. 3b). For the 5 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst, the formation of La2O2CO3 during catalyst preparation was almost entirely hindered by the generation of homogeneous La2O3·xPdO phase (Figs. 1 and 2). As expected, the typical morphology and structure of La2O2CO3 and Pd nanoparticles disappeared in Fig. 3c. In addition to Pd/La2O3 catalysts, 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst was characterized by TEM. As shown in Fig. 3d, the active Pd nanoparticles were finely dispersed on the SiO2 support with high specific surface area. XPS has been performed to characterize the Pd/SiO2 and Pd/La2O3 catalysts. There is no other carbon specie found in the C1s spectrum of Pd/SiO2, in addition to the reference adventitious carbon ( Fig. 4a). However, two other carbon group peaks, located at 288.8 and 289.6 eV, were observed in the C1s spectra of Pd/La2O3 catalysts. The peak at 289.6 eV is assigned to the CO3 2- specie of La2O2CO3, while the peak at 288.8 eV may be related to the C-O or O-CO species [36,43]. The CO3 2- specie in the C1s spectra of Pd/La2O3 catalysts originates from the La2O2CO3. As expected, the peak intensity of CO3 2- group decreased obviously with the increasing of Pd content, and almost disappeared in the C1s spectrum of 5 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The same change trend was also presented by the O group peak of CO3 2- in the O1s spectra of Pd/La2O3 catalysts (Fig. 4b). The recorded O 1 s spectra of Pd/La2O3 catalysts were well split into four group peaks at about 529.1, 531.1, 531.7 and 532.3 eV, which can be assigned to the lattice oxygen species (Olatt), the chemically adsorbed oxygen species (Oads), the oxygen species of CO3 2- and the physically adsorbed oxygen species (e.g. H2O), respectively [30,36,44–46]. Only one characteristic band of lattice oxygen species in SiO2 was found at about 533.0 eV in the O1s spectrum of Pd/SiO2 catalyst [47]. It was worth noting that the peak intensities corresponding to the Oads in these four catalysts were significantly different. The observed Oads peak intensity followed the order: 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3> 1 wt% Pd/La2O3> 5 wt% Pd/La2O3> 1 wt% Pd/SiO2. Simultaneously, the ratios of Oads/(Oads+Olatt) in these four catalysts were calculated, and the results are shown in Table 1. It was found that the calculated Oads/(Oads+Olatt) values of Pd/La2O3 catalysts (38.5–62.1 %) were much higher than Pd/SiO2 catalyst. The Oads species are generally related to the chemically adsorbed oxygen on the oxygen vacancies in catalyst sample [29]. Thus, it can be inferred that there are more oxygen vacancies in Pd/La2O3 catalyst, compared to Pd/SiO2 catalyst. The Pd valence states in Pd/SiO2 and Pd/La2O3 catalysts were investigated. As shown in Fig. 4c, all the Pd 3d spectra of these samples can be well fitted to two group peaks. The peaks at the binding energies of 335.4 and 340.8 eV are indexed as the metallic Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2, while the other two peaks are assigned to the Pd2+ specie [2]. Both the metallic Pd (Pd0) and oxidized Pd (Pd2+) exist in Pd/SiO2 and Pd/La2O3 catalysts. The active Pd mainly exists as the metallic Pd in 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3, 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 and 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalysts. In contrast, the main Pd2+ specie was obtained in 5 wt% Pd/La2O3, due to the presence of large numbers of La2O3·xPdO phase. Fig. S2 shows the La 3d spectra of Pd/La2O3 catalysts. The typical doublet peaks of La3+ were found in all the spectra of Pd/La2O3 catalysts. The SMSI between Pd and La2O3 may induce the electron transfer from Pd to La [15]. Thus, the observed La 3d binding energy of 5 wt% Pd/La2O3 was slight lower than those of other two catalysts, because the strongest SMSI effect in this catalyst. EPR characterization is widely employed to determine the existence of oxygen vacancies in samples [48,49]. To further confirm the existence of oxygen vacancies in Pd/La2O3 catalysts, the EPR spectra were recorded ( Fig. 5). The EPR signal at the g-value of about 2.003, corresponding to the electron trapping on oxygen vacancies, was barely visible for 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst, indicating that the oxygen vacancies in this sample is negligible [48,50]. In comparison, the obvious signal peaks were observed in the EPR spectra of Pd/La2O3 catalysts. It was found that the EPR signal significantly weakened with the increase of Pd content in Pd/La2O3 catalysts. The oxygen vacancy concentration of Pd/La2O3 catalysts with lower Pd content is expected to higher than that of Pd/La2O3 catalysts with higher Pd content, because of the proportional relationship between the concentration of oxygen vacancy and the peak intensity of EPR signal [50]. This conclusion was supported by the above XPS analysis (Fig. 4b). 3.2 HDF of 4-FP over supported Pd catalyst HDF of 4-FP over 1 wt% Pd catalysts with different support were investigated at mild conditions, and the results are shown in Fig. 6a and S1. It was found that the 4-FP was degraded very slowly by 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst. The defluorination of 4-FP within 120 min reaction time was less than 20 %, suggesting a low HDF activity of Pd/SiO2 catalyst at mild conditions. The poor HDF abilities were also presented by the 1 wt% Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/CNTs catalysts. Surprisingly, the Pd/La2O3 catalyst with the same Pd content of 1 wt% showed a high HDF activity. The 4-FP can be degraded completely during 120 min at mild conditions. The TOF values of Pd/SiO2 and Pd/La2O3 catalysts were calculated. As shown in Fig. 6b, the calculated TOF value of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst was very low (0.00485 min−1). In comparison, the TOF of 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst reached a high value of 0.08058 min−1, which is about 16 times of that of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst. In order to explore the key factor which is responsible for the high HDF activity of Pd/La2O3 catalyst, the main physical and chemical properties of Pd/SiO2 and Pd/La2O3 catalysts with the same Pd content of 1 wt% were carefully compared. The 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst has higher specific surface area, higher Pd dispersion and smaller Pd particle size than 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst (Table 1). These properties are beneficial to the catalytic hydrodehalogenation process. The active Pd valence state of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst is also similar to that of 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst (Fig. 4c). However, the observed HDF efficiency of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst was far lower than 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst. There must be some other dominant factors resulting in the high HDF efficiency of 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst at mild conditions. XPS and EPR results confirmed a great concentration difference of oxygen vacancy in these two catalysts (Figs. 4b and 5). There are abundant oxygen vacancies in 1 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst, and the oxygen vacancies in 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst are negligible. It was well known that the oxygen vacancies in catalyst played an important promoting role in oxidation processes (e.g. photocatalytic oxidation) [29,50,51]. The oxygen atom can be facilely activated by the localized electrons at the surface oxygen vacancies [29]. Recently, a possible promoting effect of oxygen vacancies has also been reported during catalytic hydrodechlorination (HDC) of chlorophenols [52]. For the Pd/La2O3 catalyst, the oxygen vacancies (v o) are mainly generated from the interaction between the adsorbed CO2 and the lattice oxygen (Olatt) of La2O3 (Eq. (1)), accompanied by the formation of La2O2CO3 [53]. This process is hindered by the SMSI effect which depends on the Pd content in Pd/La2O3 catalyst. (1) C O 2 + O l a t t → C O 3 + v o Therefore, the oxygen vacancy concentration in Pd/La2O3 catalyst can be easily adjusted by changing the Pd loading. To confirm the relationship between the oxygen vacancies and HDF activity, the HDF performances of Pd/La2O3 catalysts with various Pd content were evaluated. As shown in Fig. 6a and b, both the defluorination of 4-FP and the calculated TOF value followed the order: 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 > 1 wt% Pd/La2O3> 5 wt% Pd/La2O3, which is consistent with the change trend of oxygen vacancies in these catalysts (Table 1 and Fig. 5). These results demonstrated that the HDF activity was positively correlated with the concentration of oxygen vacancies in catalyst. The same positive correlation was also observed, even considering the Pd/SiO2 catalyst. It can be concluded that the HDF activity was mainly determined by the oxygen vacancies in catalyst. The catalyst with rich oxygen vacancies exhibited a much higher HDF activity than the catalyst with poor oxygen vacancies. For the 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 with rich oxygen vacancies, the estimated TOF value (0.34293 min−1) is more than 70 times that of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst. 3.3 Kinetic study In the HDH process, the halophenol is generally dehalogenated to phenol and then further hydrogenated to cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol [15]. Phenol is widely reported as the main product during Pd-catalyzed hydrodehalogenation, due to the relative low phenol hydrogenation ability of Pd [15,31]. Interestingly, the phenol produced during HDF of 4-FP is trace for 1 wt% and 5 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalysts, and even undetected for 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst ( Fig. 7a-c). The cyclohexanone, with an extremely high selectivity (>95 %), is the dominant product during HDF of 4-FP over Pd/La2O3 catalyst. Based on the above experimental results, we postulate that there maybe two pathways during HDF of 4-FP over Pd/La2O3 catalyst ( Scheme 1). The first route (denoted as Route I) is that the 4-FP is hydrodefluorinated to phenol and then hydrogenated to cyclohexanone. Another route (denoted as Route II) is the direct hydrodefluorination of 4-FP to form cyclohexanone. The kinetic study during HDF of 4-FP over Pd/La2O3 catalyst was conducted, relying on the reaction pathway outlined in Scheme 1. The catalytic hydrodehalogenation reaction well follows the pseudo-first-order kinetics [2,15,23]. Therefore, the HDF kinetic equations in this work are expressed as follows: (2) d C 4 − F P d t = − ( k 1 + k 2 ) C 4 − F P (3) d C p h e n o l d t = k 2 C 4 − F P − k 3 C p h e n o l (4) d C c y c l o h e x a n o n e d t = k 1 C 4 − F P + k 3 C p h e n o l Integrating the Eqs. (2)–(4) with the initial values, the rate constants could be calculated as follows: (5) C 4 − F P = C 4 − F P 0 exp ( − ( k 1 + k 2 ) t ) (6) C p h e n o l = k 2 C 4 − F P 0 k 3 − k 1 − k 2 ( exp ( − ( k 1 + k 2 ) t ) − exp ( − k 3 t ) ) (7) C c y c l o h e x a n o n e = k 2 k 3 C 4 − F P 0 k 3 − k 1 − k 2 ( − 1 k 1 + k 2 ( exp ( − ( k 1 + k 2 ) t ) − 1 ) + 1 k 3 ( exp ( − k 3 t ) − 1 ) ) − k 1 C 4 − F P 0 k 1 + k 2 ( exp ( − ( k 1 + k 2 ) t ) − 1 ) These equations were employed to fit the experimental data. A satisfactory agreement was obtained between the experimental and predicted concentration-time curves (Fig. 7a-c). The calculated kinetic constant values for each experiment are summarized in Table S1. All the estimated k1 values are far higher than the k2 values, revealing that the Route II is dominant during HDF of 4-FP over Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The calculated k1 value decreased with the increase of Pd content (Fig. 7d), which is well consistent with the change of oxygen vacancies in catalyst. However, the k2 value seemed to be independent to the oxygen vacancies and positively correlated with the Pd content. A higher k2 value was obtained for the catalyst with more active Pd. Therefore, the oxygen vacancies in Pd/La2O3 catalyst promote the HDF of 4-FP by accelerating the direct hydrodefluorination of 4-FP to form cyclohexanone (Route II). 3.4 HDF mechanism of 4-FP over Pd/La2O3 catalyst The hydrodehalogenation mechanism study of halophenols in literature focuses on the hydrodechlorination of chlorophenols. The mechanism, involving the direct oxidative addition of chlorophenols on the active metal (e.g. Pd) and reductive elimination with the adsorbed atomic hydrogen (Hads), was widely reported [52,54]. Its rate is determined by the number of active metal site, and the phenol is the main intermediate product or final product. This reaction mechanism should occur during HDF of 4-FP over Pd/La2O3 catalyst. In the F1s spectrum of Pd/La2O3 catalyst impregnated with 4-FP, the obviously binding energy located at about 685.5 eV, which can be indexed as Pd-bound F species, was observed ( Fig. 8a) [55,56]. The presence of Pd-bound F species in the Pd/La2O3 catalyst after 4-FP adsorption strongly suggested the occurrence of oxidative addition of 4-FP on the active Pd. The direct oxidative addition of 4-FP on the active Pd is expected to be the slow rate-limiting step in this mechanism, because of the high stability of C-F bond. By considering the intermediate product, the observed reaction rate, and the relationship between the reaction rate and the number of active Pd sites, there is a well consistency between the above reaction mechanism and the kinetic behavior of Route I. Recently, an F spillover mechanism also involving the oxidative addition of 4-FP on the Pd surface and the spillover of F onto the support (CeO2) was reported during HDF over Pd/CeO2 catalyst [57,58]. The spillover of F onto the CeO2 support is expected to result in the formation of CeFx species in catalyst. For the Pd/La2O3 catalyst impregnated with 4-FP, no peaks corresponding to LaFx phase were found in the XRD and La 3d spectrum (Fig. S3). Thus, the F spillover mechanism may not occur during HDF of FPs over Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The phenolic compounds may undergo the dissociative adsorption on the surface of metal oxide support (e.g. CeO2), generally accompanied by the color change of support [52,59]. An obvious color change was observed for the La2O2CO3 with the adsorption of 4-FP (Fig. S4). The La2O2CO3 before and after 4-FP adsorption in hexane solution were characterized by IR. As shown in Fig. 8b, three new bands, located at 1228, 1280 and 3623 cm−1, were found in the IR spectrum of 4-FP absorbed on La2O2CO3. The band at 1228 cm−1 matches the vibrational frequency of the C-F bond of pure 4-FP. For pure 4-FP, the vibrational frequencies of O-H and C-O bonds were observed at 3609 and 1260 cm−1, respectively [60]. It was worth noting that these two bands shifted to higher vibrational energy in the La2O2CO3 absorbed 4-FP (Fig. 8c-d). The band at 1280 cm−1 can be attributed to the C-O stretch of phenoxy species bonded to metal lanthanum cation [52,59], which is possibly formed by the strong Lewis acid-base interaction between cationic lanthanum and anionic oxygen [15]. The band at 3623 cm−1 is well assigned to the O-H stretch of bridged-bonded OH species with metal cation [61]. These results revealed that the 4-FP underwent the dissociative adsorption on the surface of La2O2CO3, leading to the formation of La-bound phenoxy species and La-bound hydroxyl groups. Previously study confirmed that the dissociative adsorption of halophenols occurred on the oxygen vacancy sites in catalyst, which greatly improved the hydrodehalogenation process [52]. The oxygen vacancies in Pd/La2O3 catalyst seemed to be beneficial to the oxidative addition step of 4-FP on active Pd, which was supported by the XPS results. The F1s spectrum of Pd/La2O3 catalyst with 4-FP adsorption can be split into the main peak of Pd-F and relatively weak peak of C-F (Fig. 8a), indicating that most of the C-F in the La-bound phenoxy species is oxidatively added on the active Pd. The produced new La-bound phenoxy species after reductive elimination is easily hydrogenated to cyclohexanone, since the La cation with an empty p orbital activates the phenolic ring for nucleophilic attack through the Lewis acid-aromatic ring interaction [15,59]. Additionally, the La cation can induce strong Lewis acid-base interaction with the carbonyl group of cyclohexanone, impeding further hydrogenation of cyclohexanone [15,62]. Therefore, the enhanced reaction rate and main product of cyclohexanone were obtained for the HDF mechanism involving the dissociative adsorption activation of 4-FP over Pd/La2O3 catalyst. This mechanism corresponds well to the kinetic behavior of Route II in which the 4-FP was directly hydrodefluorinated to cyclohexanone. As expected, the reaction rate (k1) of oxygen vacancy promoting mechanism presents a positive correlation with oxygen vacancies in catalyst. Based on the characterization results and kinetic study, it can be concluded that the 4-FP undergoes two different HDF mechanisms on the surface of Pd/La2O3 catalyst ( Fig. 9). In the mechanism not involving the dissociative adsorption activation of 4-FP (Route I), the 4-FP is directly oxidatively added on the active Pd, then reductively eliminated to form phenol by the adsorbed atomic hydrogen. The intermediate product phenol would be further hydrogenated to cyclohexanone. In the dominant oxygen vacancy promoting mechanism (Route II), the 4-FP is firstly activated on the oxygen vacancies in Pd/La2O3 catalyst through dissociative adsorption. The formed La-bound phenoxy species then undergo the oxidative addition, reductive elimination and are finally hydrogenated to cyclohexanone. 3.5 HDF optimization Pd is the active component during HDF, which is responsible for H2 activation and participates in oxidative addition-reductive elimination cycle of fluorophenols [15,52,54]. In the case of the sample without active Pd loading, the observed defluorination of 4-FP is negligible (Fig. S5). The HDF efficiency was enhanced remarkably after Pd loading. All the Pd/La2O3 catalysts exhibited much higher 4-FP defluorination than the pure support. It was clear that the HDF efficiency of Pd/La2O3 catalyst was greatly influenced by the Pd content in catalyst. The defluorination of 4-FP over Pd/La2O3 catalyst increased significantly with the increasing of Pd content from 0.1 to 0.2 wt%. However, the generation of oxygen vacancies is hindered by the SMSI effect in the Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The Pd/La2O3 catalyst with higher Pd content has fewer oxygen vacancies than that with lower Pd content. Therefore, further increasing Pd content in catalyst (> 0.2 wt%) would result in the decline of HDF efficiency, because the oxygen vacancy promoting reaction mechanism is dominant during HDF of 4-FP over Pd/La2O3 catalyst. Among all the prepared Pd/La2O3 catalysts, the 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst is the most promising choice for achieving high HDF efficiency. The influence of 4-FP concentration on the HDF performance over 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst was investigated. As shown in Table S2, the defluorination of 4-FP was improved dramatically by decreasing the initial 4-FP concentration. The 4-FP defluorination was only 23.3 % at the initial 4-FP concentration of 5 mmol/L. However, the complete defluorination of 4-FP can be obtained during 120 min, as the initial 4-FP concentration is lower than 0.5 mmol/L. The HDF efficiency is also affected by the catalyst dosage. As expected, the defluorination of 4-FP increased with the increasing of catalyst dosage. To achieve the complete defluorination of 4-FP during HDF over Pd/La2O3 catalyst, the conditions of 0.5 mmol/L 4-FP and 0.5 g/L catalyst dosage is recommended. Finally, three successive tests were carried out at the recommended reaction conditions for the catalytic stability evaluation. As shown in Fig. 10, a good HDF stability was presented by the Pd/La2O3 catalyst (0.2 wt%). The observed 4-FP defluorination was still a high value of about 93 % in the third run. The used Pd/La2O3 catalyst was also characterized by TEM and element mapping. No obvious structural change was found, by comparing the morphology, active Pd particle size and composition of fresh and used Pd/La2O3 catalyst (Fig. 3 and S6). These results indicate that the Pd/La2O3 catalyst is structurally stable during HDF. The slight decline of HDF efficiency during the recycling process may be attributed to the inevitable loss of catalyst in catalyst separation operation. 4 Conclusions A series of Pd/La2O3 catalysts were developed for the efficient hydrodefluorination of FPs at mild conditions, using La2O3 as the catalyst support. During the catalyst preparation, the La2O3 reacts with the CO2 in air, leading to the formation of La2O2CO3 and generation of oxygen vacancies. This reaction between La2O3 and CO2 is greatly hindered by the SMSI effect which depends on the Pd content in Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The Pd/La2O3 catalyst with a higher Pd content has fewer oxygen vacancies than that with lower Pd content. The HDF performance of fluorophenols (4-FP) was investigated in a batch reactor system. In comparison with other supported Pd catalysts (Pd/SiO2, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/CNTs), the Pd/La2O3 catalyst with the same Pd content of 1 wt% exhibited significantly higher HDF activity. It was found that the HDF efficiency of Pd/La2O3 catalyst was mainly determined by the oxygen vacancies in catalyst. The 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst with rich oxygen vacancies has the highest HDF activity. The calculated TOF of this catalyst during HDF reaches to a extremely high value of 0.34293 min−1, which is more than 70 times of that of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst. For achieving complete defluorination of 4-FP during HDF over 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst, the conditions of 0.5 mmol/L 4-FP and 0.5 g/L catalyst dosage are recommended. Kinetic and mechanism studies revealed that the 4-FP underwent two different HDF mechanisms on the surface of Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The mechanism, not involving the dissociative adsorption activation of 4-FP, proceeds very slowly. In contrast, the dominant oxygen vacancy promoting mechanism shows a far higher reaction rate. In the oxygen vacancy promoting mechanism, the 4-FP is dissociatively absorbed on the oxygen vacancies in the Pd/La2O3 catalyst, followed by the oxidative addition, reductive elimination and hydrogenation to form cyclohexanone. coredata.dc:description: The efficient hydrodefluorination at mild conditions is a huge challenge during catalytic hydrodefluorination for the treatment of wastewater containing fluorophenols. The application of lanthanum oxide as the catalyst support for the Pd-catalyzed hydrodefluorination of fluorophenols was proposed. It was found that the Pd/La2O3 catalyst exhibited a much higher HDF activity than other catalysts. Further investigation of the reaction kinetic and mechanism revealed that the oxygen vacancy promoting mechanism was dominant during HDF of 4-fluorophenol over Pd/La2O3 catalyst. The 0.2 wt% Pd/La2O3 catalyst with rich oxygen vacancies has a high HDF activity, fully degrading the 4-fluorophenol within 120 min at mild condition. The calculated TOF of this catalyst (0.34293 min−1) is more than 70 times that of 1 wt% Pd/SiO2 catalyst, making it to be a promising candidate for the hydrodefluorination of fluorophenols.
